Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PPoSS: Planning: Scalable Systems for Probabilistic Programming

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Statistical methods have had great successes for exploring data, making predictions, and solving problems in a wide range of problems. But in the world of big data, methods need to be scalable, so as to handle larger problems while modeling the real-world problems of messy and nonrepresentative data. The projectâ€™s novelties are developments in software and hardware facilitating full-stack integration of Bayesian inference to allow complex and realistic models to be fit to large datasets. The project's impacts are in many areas of pure and applied science, including fields as diverse as epidemiology, genetics, and political science, which are challenging because they are dense in parameters rather than in data. Examples include models for disease progression and drug development, decision making under uncertainty, and trends in public opinion.<br/><br/>The project is exploring probabilistic programming, including hardware, high-performance computing, programming languages and compilers, and algorithms. The ultimate goal is to develop the tools necessary for an efficient, and scalable Bayesian workflow, building on the existing success of the open-source probabilistic programming language Stan. The team of researchers on this project are working on explorations of algorithms (model validation for approximate inference), programming languages and compilers (automating of approximate algorithms and advanced performance profiling), systems (probabilistic programming for streaming data), high-performance computing (parallel processing and GPUs), and hardware (exploring domain-specific hardware for Bayesian computation).<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Policies in a wide range of areas – including education, medicine, and public health – are strongly influenced by statistical analyses of efficacy. These tools ultimately rely on the full stack of computing: from hardware and high-performance computing to programming languages, compilers, and algorithms. In this project, we have made improvements on each part of the stack to support more effective modeling, and ultimately better decision-making. In particular, we have developed tools to define and explore the design space for sparse tensor hardware accelerators that can be used to efficiently process these workloads. We have also made progress on resource-efficient and fast probabilistic programming – including for problems where new data is continuously streaming in. Some of our probabilistic programming work has been integrated into the widely-used probabilistic programming language Stan. On the algorithmic level, we have developed and theoretically analyzed approximations for some widely used models; approximations are desirable as we aim to allow faster and more user-friendly data analysis without sacrificing accuracy. To aid development of trust in the decision resulting from this full stack, we have developed a taxonomy delineating where trust in a data analysis can break down across the stack; we highlight steps that can be taken to build trust, steps where existing research work on trust tends to concentrate, and steps where establishing trust is particularly challenging.
